candidates.name: United Premium Foods
candidates.description: Full-service USDA and FDA-inspected co-packer specializing in AAFCO-compliant human-grade fresh premium pet foods; offers R&D, ingredient sourcing, cooking, blending, and packaging from small to high-volume runs.[web:393]
fit_notes: Already manufactures fresh human-grade dog food to AAFCO standards, so they understand vet-grade requirements and QA.[web:393]
Service offering explicitly includes custom formulation and private-label manufacturing, which maps well to Dogology’s model-driven, proprietary recipes.[web:393]
East Coast location with established logistics network for regional/national cold-chain distribution.
risks: Likely to have MOQs and slotting constraints; will need strong projected volume or premium positioning.
You’ll need to validate willingness to do true 'kit' SKUs (separate pouches for meats, veg, oils) vs single finished chubs.

candidates.name: Karn Meats
candidates.type: USDA human-grade pet food and fully cooked meat co-packer
candidates.description: USDA and FDA-inspected, SQF-certified facility that offers co-manufacturing of human-grade, gently cooked pet food products using real meat, fruits, and vegetables.[web:392]
fit_notes: Markets specifically as a 'human grade pet food' supplier with custom product development and co-packing, including cooked and frozen formats.[web:392]
Likely comfortable running multiple SKUs and doing portioned packs, which aligns with multi-component kit assembly.
Midwestern location can be advantageous for sourcing beef/poultry and central distribution.
risks: Smaller than some national brands; capacity for very large volumes would need to be confirmed.
You’ll have to design the kit assembly flow (multiple components per box) on top of their core cooked-food processes.

candidates.name: JustFoodForDogs – Master Kitchens (Strategic Partner)
candidates.type: Fresh dog food brand with large USDA kitchens
candidates.description: Operates large 'master kitchens' producing human-grade fresh dog food; Delaware kitchen alone built for ~30,000 lb/day and supports national expansion.[web:397][web:401]
fit_notes: Deep veterinary nutrition focus and published data about using whole-food recipes and DIY nutrient blends.[web:377][web:383]
Existing infrastructure for sourcing, cooking, batch testing, and cold-chain distribution at scale.[web:397][web:401]
Conceptually close to your DIY-plus-premix idea; a white-label or co-developed 'Dogology HealthSpan Kit' line is plausible.
risks: They are a branded competitor; may resist white-label manufacturing unless there is a compelling joint value prop.
Governance/IP boundaries around your MER model and their recipe IP would need careful structuring.

candidates.name: Freshpet
candidates.type: Branded human-grade refrigerated pet food manufacturer
candidates.description: Large-scale producer of refrigerated fresh pet food with SQF-certified kitchens, APHIS/FDA registration, and robust food-safety and sourcing standards.[web:402]
fit_notes: Serious QA and safety infrastructure; strong at chilled, high-throughput production and distribution to national retail.[web:402]
Their focus on freshness and minimally processed food aligns with your 'cook at home' narrative.
risks: Heavily retail- and brand-focused; less obvious that they’ll entertain custom kit co-manufacturing for a startup.
Process and line design are optimized for finished rolls/chubs, not multi-component meal kits.

candidates.name: Raised Right (or similar boutique human-grade brands)
candidates.type: Boutique human-grade fresh pet food brand
candidates.description: Smaller human-grade fresh pet food companies that emphasize traceable sourcing, batch testing, and transparency; good cultural fit for a high-trust, data-rich kit concept.[web:394][web:399]
fit_notes: Strong alignment on 'radical transparency' and human-grade positioning.[web:394][web:399]
Potential flexibility to experiment with kit-style SKUs and joint storytelling around provenance and data.
risks: Limited capacity and higher unit costs; better suited for small-batch pilots than for national scale.
Manufacturing might already be with a third-party co-packer you’d need to work through.
